componenttext: Can you kind of just walk through the laundry list of upcoming competitions that we should keep an eye on? I mean, we all kind of no trainers happening and maybe you can make some commentary on that, but what's on that list of stuff we should keep our eyes out for?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ron, this is Bruce. Did you say competitions or just big awards coming up or...
componenttext: Ron, this is Bruce. Did you say competitions or just big awards coming up or...

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Competitions. So you got trainer and then what else do we have on the horizon?
componenttext: Competitions. So you got trainer and then what else do we have on the horizon?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's not a whole lot of, I'll say, large-dollar strategic competitions coming up, even trainer is likely going to be -- well, the decision is likely going to happen in 2017 as opposed to 2016. I mean, another large one that we're watching SJ stars, but
componenttext: There's not a whole lot of, I'll say, large-dollar strategic competitions coming up, even trainer is likely going to be -- well, the decision is likely going to happen in 2017 as opposed to 2016. I mean, another large one that we're watching SJ stars, but that's probably not a 2016 decision either. Most -- frankly, most of the, I'll say, strategic compositions that are, I think, is at the heart of your questions would probably not be in 2016. I mean, these are things like long-range or the LRSO competition, the GBMD, GSBB, excuse me, ground strategic business ballistic deterrent. But those are probably '17 and even beyond as far as other real big ticket strategic items. And beyond that, the one we're watching obviously closely, which I wouldn't characterize but Leeds in Germany is one that we're open to close at the latter part of the year, and I'll let Marillyn add some color to what I just said.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only other ones I would say that we're watching is some of our international partners making their decision on is coming through the process and Canada ultimately we think the best choice for them is F-35, but they'll go through their process for that
componenttext: The only other ones I would say that we're watching is some of our international partners making their decision on is coming through the process and Canada ultimately we think the best choice for them is F-35, but they'll go through their process for that.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Robert Spingarn with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Robert Spingarn with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask really a 2-part question on IS&GS, if I could. First, I think as you both stayed that the business is doing a little better than perhaps you guided before. You tweaked up the guidance there. I want to talk about whether that this just timi
componenttext: I wanted to ask really a 2-part question on IS&GS, if I could. First, I think as you both stayed that the business is doing a little better than perhaps you guided before. You tweaked up the guidance there. I want to talk about whether that this just timing on some of these program closeouts or pricing environment, which I think you cited pressure and maybe a little better than expected. And separately, Marillyn, the deal was contemplated, I think, on what the business will look like at the time of transaction, but of course, that's a 9-month period. And so from the time of announcement, how do we think about some of the puts and takes and strategic things that you're doing with regard to headcount vis-a-vis the new management team? Are these things that we're negotiated? How do we think about that?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take a first part of the question, sort of the IS&GS performance. And I'll say, I mean, obviously, we increased the outlook for both sales and profit, so it's exceeded our expectations. I think there's a couple of things going on, and some of them
componenttext: Let me take a first part of the question, sort of the IS&GS performance. And I'll say, I mean, obviously, we increased the outlook for both sales and profit, so it's exceeded our expectations. I think there's a couple of things going on, and some of them are a little subtle. So sales and -- this is a tough business to sort of predict, which competitions are you going to and which ones are you going to not win and you get scenarios where things get protested even if you lose and therefore you can actually get the sales stretched out of those. We're sort of seeing all those happen at the same time. So one thing I'm really pleased with, probably more than anything even higher than sales volume because it gets a little bit hard to recall is the better-than-expected earnings performance and the margin performance. This was a quarter where we had a pretty significant write-off on an international contract. And even with that write-off, we still exceeded our expectations, and we still, as obviously, we said earlier increased our guidance for the year. I think that's sort of due to 3 reasons that as I look at the start of big picture-wise, one, we had expected a number of free compete activities to occur in some of our larger contracts in the year. And these -- we bid those probably more aggressive than the previous contract where we were the incumbent, and because these contracts are actually being protested, we are continuing the performance on the older contracts, which are the higher margin on the incumbent contracts. So it's good for us from both the sales perspective, and more importantly, on the margin side because of that. I think we also had better performance sort of the closeout or transition of some of the programs that we lost. So you should think that most of these contracts tend to have transition periods that extend for some period of time, and we're actually performing very, very well on those transition periods, have taken some cost out higher than our expectations, which are resulting in higher margins. And then the third thing I would just say is really just across the portfolio, strong performance by the IS&GS team and, I think, credit goes to that team. I think it's indicative of the fact that they haven't taken their eyes off the ball. It's a well-run organization, and the entire team understands that the mission they perform for their customers is important no matter who they work for, and I think we're seeing that play out live in person in front of us here. I'll ask Marillyn to answer the other question you asked for.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll pick up on the second part where you asked about at the time of transaction how to think about some of the puts and takes in the headcount and how we think about that. First of all, I just want to build what Bruce said. I mean, this is a managem
componenttext: Yes. I'll pick up on the second part where you asked about at the time of transaction how to think about some of the puts and takes in the headcount and how we think about that. First of all, I just want to build what Bruce said. I mean, this is a management team is running a business. They've outlined some commitments for the year and we're performing the commitments and the whole team in IS&GS is making sure that their cost structure is in line with the business base that they have. So as they look at what they need to do to be competitive in a very competitive environment that they operate in, it's ultracompetitive, and it's an area that you got to constantly be watching your cost and you have to manage that. There's close coordination with Leidos as they make headcount reductions. Certainly, we have an agreement as we're going through this process quoting the transaction, so actions that we take on the Lockheed Martin side if they are aware that are going to take those kinds of actions, but it is our job to continue to run the business to perform well on the business. It's in all of our best interest, and we will continue to do that with an excellent team that's working on that every day.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Strauss of UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Strauss of UBS.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions within one, I guess. First, can you talk about the only 6 F-35s that were delivered in the quarter. Was that your plan or was that actually below that -- below your plan? And then on Sikorsky, can you talk about -- it looks like MFC
componenttext: A couple of questions within one, I guess. First, can you talk about the only 6 F-35s that were delivered in the quarter. Was that your plan or was that actually below that -- below your plan? And then on Sikorsky, can you talk about -- it looks like MFC that you're guiding for fairly flat EBIT from here through the rest of the year, but I would think the, as you've commented, Sikorsky is expected to get better and whether you're still tracking a plan for Sikorsky as a neutral earnings in 2017.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the 6 F-35s, probably a little lighter than we expected, and there's probably 3 or 4 different reasons for that, but none of them that will play out, I think, by the time we get to the end of the second quarter. And I think we'll be back on track at th
componenttext: So the 6 F-35s, probably a little lighter than we expected, and there's probably 3 or 4 different reasons for that, but none of them that will play out, I think, by the time we get to the end of the second quarter. And I think we'll be back on track at the end of the second quarter, and we're very much on track to have the 53 aircraft that we talked about in the first quarter or the last call in January, excuse me, delivered for the year. So no issue there. It was just a transition between lots and getting new acceptance for new software and the like that delayed some of the deliveries. But sort of from a production or manufacturing side, there is no issue. There is more of a not quite administrative but not a production issue there. You talked about Sikorsky within MST, and our guidance looks like sort of flat earnings for the rest of the year. That's what we're showing, David, in the outlook there. And even with the $50 million increase in guidance from an earnings perspective with MST, that's one that we're watching closely. It's a little early in the the year to go more than that, but I think there is some potential upside in the numbers that we've got on the table right now. If you just do the math the way you did it, David, with including the Sikorsky uptick for the rest of the 3 quarters of the year, you can come to that conclusion as well. And then lastly, the -- I think the Sikorsky, you asked about Sikorsky being neutral in EPS, so all this has to do with the share reduction from the reverse Morris stress transaction and expectation of some of the bleed-off of transition costs are transaction costs including the integration. That's still our expectation, David, is that we'll be neutral going into 2017 with all the pluses and minuses going into that.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Peter Arment with Stern Agee.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Peter Arment with Stern Agee.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bruce, question on kind of just big picture on the backlog. You closed 2015 at record level and then a little bit of a downtick here this quarter. I guess timing-related. On IS&GS you're going to lose of that. Is there a number we kind of should be lookin
componenttext: Bruce, question on kind of just big picture on the backlog. You closed 2015 at record level and then a little bit of a downtick here this quarter. I guess timing-related. On IS&GS you're going to lose of that. Is there a number we kind of should be looking for, for what you think backlog ends up at the end of the year. And then Marillyn, in a related to that how you're looking at the international front we've seen a healthy drop in oil over the last 18 months. We haven't seen a big impact on your awards but just seeing if you're seeing any behavior changes.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Peter, I'll answer the backlog question. So we were down in the quarter after the record backlog ended the last year. Actually, we were ahead of plan in the first quarter, I think a couple of billion dollars worth or so. So that may not be apparent. Even
componenttext: Peter, I'll answer the backlog question. So we were down in the quarter after the record backlog ended the last year. Actually, we were ahead of plan in the first quarter, I think a couple of billion dollars worth or so. So that may not be apparent. Even though it's down, that's not down as much as what our plan suggested it might be. An interesting thing we're going to have, probably a little bit of an opposite or unusual pattern to backlog this year or at least as we see it, is the orders that this year wheel probably not as large a fourth quarter from a little as we ordinarily would. The largest quarter is actually third quarter this year, and that's sort of the planning and the biggest single ticket item there is the or award of the LRIP 10 contract on F-35, and that's worth a significant amount of money. Depending on when that happens and when IS&GS is dispositioned, we can actually see potentially $100 billion [ph] worth of backlog that will quickly dissipate with IS&GS disposition. And if I was to pick a number, it's probably going to be somewhere between 90 and -- low 90s to $95 billion, excuse me, by year-end as the expectation. We were sort of expecting about it almost $4.5 million or so $5 billion drop steady run rate with IS&GS in the mix and when you take out IS&GS it gets down to that $90-ish billion level.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Peter, I'll pick up on your question relative to impact of oil prices and what it might -- what we're seeing on our rewards. We often talk about this because retrying to watch. We're not seeing a pullback on essential national security assets and what the
componenttext: Peter, I'll pick up on your question relative to impact of oil prices and what it might -- what we're seeing on our rewards. We often talk about this because retrying to watch. We're not seeing a pullback on essential national security assets and what these countries needs. What we are seeing is that there's a couple of them that are watching and one that's in our numbers that we're watching very closely is the cutter that there because that's something we're hoping to have in this year, and it is in our plan. It could potentially delay. I think it's not an indication they're not going to buy it. To me, it's just a matter of them balancing the pressure on their budgets the oil prices balancing what they can buy, and I think that we'll see probably some of that. Maybe it will impact some volumes or delays and some orders but the bottom line is the conflict in that region, you know the challenges they have the global security standpoint and because they have increased security responsibility since the U.S. is not so prevalent there, they're having to step up and buy the things that we need -- that they need in order to protect their citizens. So we anticipate continued demand. It's just a matter of maybe some things will slip. That's not unusual in the international marketplace even on a good day. We don't always see things come right online with what we anticipate anyway because as they're dealing with multiple procurements, they may have to do it more serially sometimes and get one out of the way before they move onto the next, so we have to wait through that process.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Sam Pearlstein from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Sam Pearlstein from Wells Fargo.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about ULA? You had said you thought it will be flattish this year. It looks like it was down a little in the first quarter. And at least the press talked about a further headcount reduction this year and then again next year. So
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about ULA? You had said you thought it will be flattish this year. It looks like it was down a little in the first quarter. And at least the press talked about a further headcount reduction this year and then again next year. So just trying to think about how severance would flow through, and then if I could follow up with a second one, just in your proxy, you removed the orders category from some of the incentive comp and just kind of talk to why you would have made that change at this point.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll take the ULA question. So ULA was down in the first quarter in terms of the equity earnings. It's purely timing. We actually expect ULA's earnings will be higher in 2016 than 2015. That's actually the primary reason behind the guidance increase an
componenttext: So I'll take the ULA question. So ULA was down in the first quarter in terms of the equity earnings. It's purely timing. We actually expect ULA's earnings will be higher in 2016 than 2015. That's actually the primary reason behind the guidance increase and systems, in fact, because we do have a higher expectation of ULA. The severance charges that we're taking on ULA, I don't think you'll see much impact of that in the numbers, and that's just a little bit of -- you've got the severance cost offset by the lower cost once the people are removed, and that will, I think, at least in 2016 be somewhat neutral for the year. It's a little too early for me to call 2017, but that's the expectation for 2016. Orders in the proxy, we had a lot of discussion about that, Sam, and we actually had -- and Marillyn can comment on this as well, obviously, but we actually had a lot of discussions with the board and our compensation committee. And the concern was that because orders are so variable, I mean a perfect example perhaps is you can imagine a scenario where we had won the bomber program in 2015, but it had been protested and pushed out in 2016. Do you give actually someone credit for having won it or do you say you missed it because you didn't bring it home? These are some of the real live conversations that we had, and we ultimately decided that the sales, earnings and cash flow were better measures of the actual performance without the customer vagary going on there in terms of awards. I'll remind you also that we do have a incentive compensation metric associated with focused programs and the thought was as long as we win the right programs, I mean, whether or not -- I make this up, whether or not the fiscal year LRIP 12 on F-35 happens in December or January, it's probably not as important as winning some of our critical competitions. And so we decided to start the focus more on the critical competitions as opposed to some of the timing vagaries associated with orders that really don't influence the economics or financials of the company whether they happen again end of this year or beginning of next year.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just add to that. I think Bruce covered it well. If you look at how we outlined our incentive compensation, we have very clearly on the financials sales orders and even cash as you see. I mean where the orders come into play is in the strategic and
componenttext: Let me just add to that. I think Bruce covered it well. If you look at how we outlined our incentive compensation, we have very clearly on the financials sales orders and even cash as you see. I mean where the orders come into play is in the strategic and operational area and that is still an element of compensation. We look at it more in terms of focused programs, as Bruce said, or programs that we need to continue on contract growth within keep sold and keep them forward. But as we flow down those metrics throughout the organization, the individuals in the organization are still going to be tracking their orders. They're still going to be driving to achieve levels of financial performance on the orders front, so it's not something we've taken out. It's just that we've looked at it more realistically on how we -- what we should be compensating for in terms of incentive compensation, and it's still an element. It's just not outlined as a digital requirement.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from George Shapiro with Shapiro Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from George Shapiro with Shapiro Research.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bruce, I wanted to pursue on the F-35 margin, you said last year was 10%, obviously, including the onetime catch-ups. Given that this year the profit was only up $30 million on $400 million sales increase, obviously, that relates to having lower pickups.
componenttext: Bruce, I wanted to pursue on the F-35 margin, you said last year was 10%, obviously, including the onetime catch-ups. Given that this year the profit was only up $30 million on $400 million sales increase, obviously, that relates to having lower pickups. Could you tell us though what the F-35 margin actually was this year or maybe kind of what the run rate it's been going at?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's a little lower. The reason I highlighted the first quarter of last year, that's probably the high point of any quarter in the history of the F-35 program. And that's to say that that's what we expect eventually to become sort of standard practic
componenttext: Yes. It's a little lower. The reason I highlighted the first quarter of last year, that's probably the high point of any quarter in the history of the F-35 program. And that's to say that that's what we expect eventually to become sort of standard practice as that will be a double-digit program going forward just as F-16, F22, C-130s and you name the program are. First quarter of 2016 is a little less than 2015 but not much less. We still have good performance, and you should think of that as even though the step-ups were lower, sort of the run rate of the program is higher. And therefore, it's almost comparable but not quite to what we performed in 2016 -- excuse me, in 2015 in the first quarter compared to 2016. Run rate, as I said to the earlier question, I've lost track now who asked it, but our expectation is we still do expect to have margin improvement on the entire program, including the development contract. But the total F-35 program this year, in total, is probably 50 basis points margins higher than it was in 2015. So again, nice progression, not quite as high as the 100 basis points we talked last year but still progressing nicely and sort of in line with what I said all along, which is double-digit by the end by the time we get to full rate production.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Seth Seifman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Seth Seifman with JPMorgan.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: On F-35, I think we all understand that there's a lot of good progress that's been made but that there's also still challenges ahead. So when you think about those challenges, which we read about fairly often, if the development portion of the program was
componenttext: On F-35, I think we all understand that there's a lot of good progress that's been made but that there's also still challenges ahead. So when you think about those challenges, which we read about fairly often, if the development portion of the program was to become extended, let's say, into 2018, in terms of financial implications, I'm guessing they're fairly -- there's fairly little exposure to you. But are there concurrency implications to that or, for example, if there are issues that delay the program further, is the exposure for you sort of in going back into and making upgrades to aircraft? And could you talk about how much we should be concerned about that, if at all?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take a shot. It's a really good question, Seth. And let me just give you, hopefully, a thoughtful answer to your question there. So the challenges that we have on the development program are surely winding down as we're progressing through a lot of
componenttext: Let me take a shot. It's a really good question, Seth. And let me just give you, hopefully, a thoughtful answer to your question there. So the challenges that we have on the development program are surely winding down as we're progressing through a lot of the changes. A lot of the -- I'll say the impacts that might result -- your question sort of tallied what's going on with the concurrency changes that impact the development program stretched out. Most of the structural types of testing that could result in, I'll say, large concurrency changes, we should have a really, really good idea of where those are, probably by the end of this year or in the middle of next year as we complete sort of the testing and the multiple useful life testing of all 3 variants. We're -- I've lost track off the top of my head where we are progressing on that, but all 3 variants are well past a single useful life in terms of their durability, and we're in 150% of useful life and beyond, I believe, for where we are in the testing of that. So most of the structural items, I would say I wouldn't expect to see huge concurrency impacts. There may be some relative -- some software changes that come out of it relative to some testing and particularly some of the testing later in the development program that might result in some software changes. I don't typically view those as concurrency issues. We're still on track for the IOC of the USAF later this year. We're making really good progress on the software to accomplish that. The Alice program is probably the other thing that we all have our eyes on in terms of this is the sustainment vehicle that, sort of, is your one-stop shop for sustainment on the F-35 program. And the huge amount of software that we're doing there is high on our list of things to be mindful of, but I think that's still going to support the IOC and whatever that's scheduled in the fourth quarter or so of this year. I'll remind you the development contract is still cost reimbursable, and I know your question is more in the concurrency, but we really do think most of the concurrency risk starts to fade pretty measurably once we get past these testings the latter part of this year and to early 2017.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Myles Walton with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Myles Walton with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bruce and Marillyn, I think you talked about top line organic growth targets of the company going forward in the 3% to 5% range with the outside contributor at Aeronautics, but that's also where you did the headcount reduction actions. So 2-part questions
componenttext: Bruce and Marillyn, I think you talked about top line organic growth targets of the company going forward in the 3% to 5% range with the outside contributor at Aeronautics, but that's also where you did the headcount reduction actions. So 2-part questions. One is that still the right growth rate to think about? And two, is this more of a reactionary headcount to some of the ongoing negotiations as it relates to F-35 and/or other internal VOD competitive pressures?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me try that to begin with. I'll let Marillyn chime in, Myles, but I think I've said publicly, once you sort of strip out IS&GS and you sort of  re-baseline Lockheed Martin without IS&GS in the portfolio, I think, organically going forward, you should
componenttext: Let me try that to begin with. I'll let Marillyn chime in, Myles, but I think I've said publicly, once you sort of strip out IS&GS and you sort of  re-baseline Lockheed Martin without IS&GS in the portfolio, I think, organically going forward, you should expect this to have about 3% to 5% growth heavily driven, obviously, by the F-35 program and Aeronautics, in general. Also contributing to that is across all the business areas it may not be self evident because we've actually got some DoD contractions in some of the business areas there, but our international growth is probably going to grow from 21% or so this year to somewhere in the 25% in the not-too-distant future. So that's helping fuel that growth as well. As far as the reductions, I would say that's not because of pressure that's being put on us from a DoD perspective. There is -- if you just think of the life cycle and it goes back little bit to Seth's question there, the development program is winding down, the production program is going leaps and bounds year-over-year, and so the workforce is sort of transitioning more from sort of an engineering-dominant workforce to more of a manufacturing-based workforce, and we're starting to see that transition occur. And that's what some of these reductions are for, simply the lower level of the development program going down and the higher production program increasing without the same number of heads required to support the manufacturing growth as what we saw in the development programs, if that makes sense.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you've got that right on the mark, Bruce. But to add to that, it's also changing the nature of the work that the indirect personnel support to that, and so you don't need to the same number of people that are in certain roles as you move into the
componenttext: I think you've got that right on the mark, Bruce. But to add to that, it's also changing the nature of the work that the indirect personnel support to that, and so you don't need to the same number of people that are in certain roles as you move into the production phase and you ramp up that production.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It may not be perfectly evident, Myles, but recall, we did -- we at Lockheed Martin did responsible for the large bulk of the development program whereas the production program, obviously, is a lot more the supply chain, including 2 large partners of ther
componenttext: It may not be perfectly evident, Myles, but recall, we did -- we at Lockheed Martin did responsible for the large bulk of the development program whereas the production program, obviously, is a lot more the supply chain, including 2 large partners of there, so they are doing pretty good chumps of the aircraft production perspective, whereas we were doing more of the development program as Lockheed Martin.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Howard Rubel with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Howard Rubel with Jefferies.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marillyn, there's -- not to kina show off a little bit, but you didn't mention Pakistan F-16, and I suspect you probably have some other opportunities there. And then in addition to addressing that, would you also talk about the number of the items that a
componenttext: Marillyn, there's -- not to kina show off a little bit, but you didn't mention Pakistan F-16, and I suspect you probably have some other opportunities there. And then in addition to addressing that, would you also talk about the number of the items that are in the half mark that sure seem to play into your wheelhouse, whether it's the F-22 restart or some new air defense system opportunities?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Appreciate the question. And just from back to your question about F-16, I mean, we continue to look for opportunities for F-16, certainly Pakistan through its congressional we look forward to the opportunity on that. Bahrain, hopefully, ultimately at som
componenttext: Appreciate the question. And just from back to your question about F-16, I mean, we continue to look for opportunities for F-16, certainly Pakistan through its congressional we look forward to the opportunity on that. Bahrain, hopefully, ultimately at some point in the future, an opportunity. In India, we're continuing with our upgrade to the F-16, a lot of the the modification work like in Taiwan so...

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the potentials line started in India. We talked about...
componenttext: And the potentials line started in India. We talked about...

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right. We talked about India's looking at their taxable fighter competition, and we are in there with an offer to move our production line to India. In terms of the mark =the most recent mark that came out of the half core, the defense bill, t
componenttext: Yes, that's right. We talked about India's looking at their taxable fighter competition, and we are in there with an offer to move our production line to India. In terms of the mark =the most recent mark that came out of the half core, the defense bill, they have -- as you have seen have added 11 aircraft for the F-35 we -- and so we saw an increase last year in FY '16 that, coming forward as important. Also, a lot of our programs are well supported, just in budget itself and then with potential ads of they look at additional opportunities in the F-22, I know there's been some discussion about F-22, and we just stand ready to support with whatever information we're asked to provide. You're probably aware that the 2 exist, and so there will be as most programs from a cold start I'm sure they want to understand the cost associated with a cold start, but at the same time you wouldn't want to build the same aircraft, so you'll do some upgrades to that aircraft modernize it, and some of the design incorporates some of the things that we've learned through F-35 and other programs that you could incorporate into that. So we'll stand ready to support that. But bottom line is, I think, our program is well supported in the present budget submission, and I think the markets going through potentially add some additional and we know there's a long way to go on the budget process, it's early days in getting through that. So we remain hopeful that with our programs, they're really lined up with the department strategic priorities that we'll continue to be well supported.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Pete Skibitski with Drexel Hamilton.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Pete Skibitski with Drexel Hamilton.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate the color on Sikorsky earlier. I was wondering if you could go farther and update us on your expectations prior expectations, intangible amortization of this year and integration cost and how fast are what magnitude you expect drop off in '17
componenttext: I appreciate the color on Sikorsky earlier. I was wondering if you could go farther and update us on your expectations prior expectations, intangible amortization of this year and integration cost and how fast are what magnitude you expect drop off in '17 and '18.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take that on. So intangibles, we'd said in the January call that those might move around. I think we have a year's time to sort of set the numbers in there. I think we're real close. It's a slight improvement in the intangible amortization. When I sa
componenttext: I'll take that on. So intangibles, we'd said in the January call that those might move around. I think we have a year's time to sort of set the numbers in there. I think we're real close. It's a slight improvement in the intangible amortization. When I say slight improvement, a little bit slower, smaller intangible amortization in 2016 than we originally talked about but not enough to get too excited about, to be honest with you. The integration cost, still think that the bulk of that will be completed in 2017 and still, some of that might carry over into 2018 -- excuse me, 2017, as we look forward to. I still think, as we sit here today, that we're tracking towards what we talked when we did the acquisition, which was about $150 million or so per year of steady state savings beginning in 2018. I still think that's a good possibility that, that will be the number that we're seeing then. We've got a lot of work to do between now. And then as I said earlier, I think we're tracking very nicely to what our expectations were on Sikorsky.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our last question comes in the line of Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen.
componenttext: Our last question comes in the line of Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if we can go back to the severance charge, Bruce, $99 million, can you give us some color how does that split between arrow and IS&G, what sort of folks that you lay off? Do you expect to recover all of that this year and if so, how come the guide for
componenttext: So if we can go back to the severance charge, Bruce, $99 million, can you give us some color how does that split between arrow and IS&G, what sort of folks that you lay off? Do you expect to recover all of that this year and if so, how come the guide for Arrow and IS&G didn't go up by more than $25 million each?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think the way you should think about the severance charge, Cai, is somewhere in the range of roughly 3/4 is arrow, somewhere in the $70-ish million and the difference -- $70 million, $75 million, and the differences is in IS&GS, and they have th
componenttext: Yes. So I think the way you should think about the severance charge, Cai, is somewhere in the range of roughly 3/4 is arrow, somewhere in the $70-ish million and the difference -- $70 million, $75 million, and the differences is in IS&GS, and they have the numbers exactly you to memory, Cai, but somewhere in that range 3/4, 1/4 or so. As I said earlier and I think I was talking to Myles on the question the headcount reduction in Aeronautics most of these are salaried folks. As Marillyn said, some of the indirect support required to is no longer required support sort of the production ramp rate that was required to support some of the developmental work that we were doing. Importantly, I think, a big piece of the Aeronautics reduction was actually a voluntary reduction, and I think we actually got about what we were expecting as a result of that voluntary reductions, so we were pleased with that, that people -- they came with very few, I'll say, involuntary reductions. So I think it's a good thing as well. And then as far as the recovery of this year or not -- that's still playing out, Cai, we're trying -- I think in big picture terms that you should expect to see a somewhat neutral reaction in 2016, and there may be some benefit depending on what the timing is of the reductions or the severance charge assessed they play out that may carry on in 2017. We'll watch that closely and monitor that is to go through the next 3 quarters to see if there is an impact in 2016. But if there is, we'll surely tell you about it and if it happens in 2017, we'll try to give you insight to that quickly as well.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me conclude the call for today, and I just like to end by reiterating the corporation completed a very strong first quarter. Our robust backlog coupled with an increase in DoD budget has the corporation positioned for top line growth and in increas
componenttext: So let me conclude the call for today, and I just like to end by reiterating the corporation completed a very strong first quarter. Our robust backlog coupled with an increase in DoD budget has the corporation positioned for top line growth and in increasing cash flows into the future. Thank you again for joining us on the call today. We look forward to speaking with you in our next earnings call in July. Abigail, that includes the call today.
