componenttext: I realize this may be a little bit early to ask this question, but can you help us think about the work statement that you have with Turkey as it relates of the F-35 in the context of maybe some of the sustainment. And if you want to talk about sort of longer-term implication from some of the recent activities there as it relates to the F-35, that would be helpful.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll take that question, and then Bruce if you have anything to add. If you look at Turkey, I know there's been a lot of churn in Turkey here recently, but it still remains a very valued NATO partner for us, and NATO ally, and it's got -- it's an es
componenttext: Sure. I'll take that question, and then Bruce if you have anything to add. If you look at Turkey, I know there's been a lot of churn in Turkey here recently, but it still remains a very valued NATO partner for us, and NATO ally, and it's got -- it's an essential security partner in that region for the United States and for our allies. So we look forward to continuing our business relationship there and across a number of programs that we have. We have not seen any indication that it will impact the F-35 or any of their other programs, and we'll continue to assess the situation and make sure that we'll share what you've there's any impact on our business. Their plan is to procure 100 F-35, so they are a very important partner in the program. Bruce, anything you want to add?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the only thing I want to add, Hunter, is we got a long history with Turkey. We worked with them since the pretty early days of the F-16 program. We've actually built F-16s in Turkey, as you know. In the heart of your question, we're also doing parts
componenttext: Yes, the only thing I want to add, Hunter, is we got a long history with Turkey. We worked with them since the pretty early days of the F-16 program. We've actually built F-16s in Turkey, as you know. In the heart of your question, we're also doing parts of the F-35 at 2 [indiscernible] aerospace industries in Turkey. That relationship has been successful. As you said, it's probably early to call up the grand implications are, but they've been us Marillyn said a trusted partner with Lockheed Martin for quite sometime, and we hope that's the case in the future, obviously.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Pete Skibitski with Drexel Hamilton.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The F-35, the LRIP 910 contract to talk about the investment levels going dramatically in the coming month if it doesn't get signed, I think. Can you size that for us, and what's your sense of how close you are for the contract getting signed, and are you
componenttext: The F-35, the LRIP 910 contract to talk about the investment levels going dramatically in the coming month if it doesn't get signed, I think. Can you size that for us, and what's your sense of how close you are for the contract getting signed, and are you definitely going to cash fund it is at this and close?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so let me just give you a little bit of color. It's a good question, Pete. And so the current level, I think we disclosed in the earnings release, we got nearly $1 billion or so that we're funding on the program, and that's a decision that we made to
componenttext: Yes, so let me just give you a little bit of color. It's a good question, Pete. And so the current level, I think we disclosed in the earnings release, we got nearly $1 billion or so that we're funding on the program, and that's a decision that we made to do that. For whatever reason, the U.S. government has not decided to put funds that are authorized and appropriated to fund Lockheed Martin and our subcontractor efforts on the contracts, so w5 been -- we made the decision at the time that we were going to not allow a stop on the program and cause the disruption on the program, particularly on our supply base, since that's where most of the work is being done at this time on the F-35 LRIP 9 and 10 contracts. So w5 been funding that for a while. We continue to ask for funding recovery from the U.S. government. To this point, they've not funded us. At some point in the future because of the growth that we see over the next few months, and you should think of this literally growing, Pete, in the $400 million to $500 million per month sorts of levels. We will not be able to sustain that. So if we don't either get funding through a funding mechanism such as a funding item or we definitize the contracts, we will not be able to continue end of that level of cash outflow as a corporation. We simply don't have the capacity. The Pentagon clearly knows that situation, and I'm optimistic that we're going to get cash soon.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Rich Safran with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Rich Safran with Buckingham Research.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marillyn, Bruce, Jerry, I know I usually ask a question about programs, but today, I have one in pension income or cash fund the requirements. Now if you would, relative to where rates were or are -- were in 2015, I want to know if you could maybe discuss
componenttext: Marillyn, Bruce, Jerry, I know I usually ask a question about programs, but today, I have one in pension income or cash fund the requirements. Now if you would, relative to where rates were or are -- were in 2015, I want to know if you could maybe discuss what you expect for 2017 for FAS/CAS income. Also, can you give us maybe your best estimate regarding whether or not you're going to have a cash contribution to pension next year? If so, how much? Maybe you could give us a range in that. Anything you could give would be helpful.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take that, Rich. So we're probably a little early to be talking about it. Feels a little early if you're talking about 2017, but I think it's a fair question given all the changes that have happened in the interest rate environment recently, particul
componenttext: I'll take that, Rich. So we're probably a little early to be talking about it. Feels a little early if you're talking about 2017, but I think it's a fair question given all the changes that have happened in the interest rate environment recently, particularly after the Brexit situation, I think, what the 10-year treasury is going for at 1.4% or thereabout. So dramatic reduction from the start of the year to now. I think we ended the year at a discount rate of about 4 3/8 or 4.375%. If we were to strike a line in the sand right now, it's probably 100 basis points lower than that. You tell me whether you think it's going to increase between now and the end of the year or not. But if it did not, every 25 basis points change in the discount rate from where we ended last year is worth about $125 million delta to FAS expense. So that's a pretty significant reduction to FAS next year. The asset returns, you didn't ask about those, but that's the other component in the mix the asset returns are actually tracking pretty nicely towards an 8% return. We got a nice lift in the equity markets, particularly domestically here recently that helped with that situation. So if I were to predict, again, kind of striking the line in the sand, our current FAS/CAS in 2016 is roughly, what, $975 million or so of income. Looking forward and just carrying those impacts into 2017 that I just described, '17 would probably be $350 million, maybe $400 million lower than 2016, still income from FAS/CAS, if you will, but not as much income as what we've been expecting and talking about previously. As to your cash funding question, there is no impact next year at all associated with the discount rate change. I mean there is a risk which requires the funding levels for our pension justice sensitive to asset returns than the discount rate changes. FAS is sort of an instantaneous discount rate impact than a risk spread over time, so we wouldn't expect any change whatsoever in the funding requirements in 2017, still 0.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Joe DeNardi with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Joe DeNardi with Stifel.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bruce, I think you talked the last quarter about 2018 pension contributions, and apologies for asking a question that's so far out in the future, but you said that you think you can fill most, if not all of that gap. I'm wondering if you could provide the
componenttext: Bruce, I think you talked the last quarter about 2018 pension contributions, and apologies for asking a question that's so far out in the future, but you said that you think you can fill most, if not all of that gap. I'm wondering if you could provide the little more detail about of the $1.5 billion contribution, what's the cash tax benefit? And then what are some of the other areas you see as helping you guys fill that gap?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I actually planned to give a little more insight into the 2018 numbers, probably not October. Let me take a shot at it now just because you asked the question. So we have said, 2017 we talked about being the last of the 3-year what we call pension fund
componenttext: So I actually planned to give a little more insight into the 2018 numbers, probably not October. Let me take a shot at it now just because you asked the question. So we have said, 2017 we talked about being the last of the 3-year what we call pension funding holiday that we announced, I guess, at the beginning of 2015. As Rich asked in his question about cash funding, we don't see that changing in 2017. In previous quarters, I did talk about 2018 having a acquired pension contribution, and obviously, that's still the case. However, what I was trying to convey and the number you threw out, about $1.5 billion is flowing around there, maybe a little bit higher now. So what I was trying to convey in previous calls and I'll try to convey in this call is you should think of the current level of operating cash dropping by the full amount of pension funding in 2018, and that's really for a couple of reasons. One is we expect to get much stronger cash flows from Sikorsky in 2018 versus what we're seeing today. We expect to have higher cash flow from F-35 than we're seeing today. And then lastly, as you described in your question, we also will get a tax benefit associated with the pension cash contribution in 2018, so think about it as sort of 65% simplistically of the cash contribution is what will be a hit to operating cash in that year, if you will.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016

componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more philosophically just about capital allocation and share buyback, and now you have a target of 300 million or less than 300 million shares outstanding. But just trying to think about where the stock's multiple is now and just trying to think about how you factor that into what you view as your capital and whether that makes other alternatives more attractive than repurchasing shares.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me take a shot at that, Sam. So it's a great question as far as capital allocation plans. We still feel strongly about the dividend capital allocation to be provided to shareholders. We have  if you just look at the composition of our shareholder
componenttext: Yes, let me take a shot at that, Sam. So it's a great question as far as capital allocation plans. We still feel strongly about the dividend capital allocation to be provided to shareholders. We have  if you just look at the composition of our shareholder base, it's probably -- I don't remember, 30%, 35%. I'm looking at Jerry as I say this. 30%, 35% of our investor base is income base, so that's a pretty significant element of our ownership that is driven, in fact, by the dividend yield so that's an important aspect of capital allocation going forward. I always say that I think the best indication of what we'll do there is the track record we have in the last few years or even a decade or more relative to dividend contributions. We still have some options that have yet to be exercised. The option exercise has actually slowed down quite a bit. You might remember, Sam, you've been following us long enough years ago. We had a lot of dilution as a result of options being exercised. That level has come down quite a bit, but there's still a backlog of options out there that as those do get exercise, we will clearly do share repurchases to offset that dilution. We will do share repurchases to offset dilution from the equity compensation as well. And then from that point, Sam, as usual, this may not be the most satisfying answer you'll get, a seasonal it depends what's available at that time including other opportunities to invest in programs, acquisitions, that sort of thing, the one thing that probably don't make a whole lot of sense at least at this point is to let us just say it idly on the balance sheet making little interest as in fact it does. I'll remind you and I know you know this, Sam, that the RMT transaction will reduce share count pretty significantly on its own, probably somewhere between 9 million shares and 10 million shares at sort of current trading. And on top of that, we get the $1.8 billion special payment as I talked about and lacking a more pressing or -- what's the word I'm looking for?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016

componenttext: Opportunistic.

componenttext: Opportunistic use of that $1.8 billion, I would think a good chunk of that would probably go towards share repurchases.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Harned with Bernstein.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm interested. And Bruce said -- and you clearly had a very good quarter, and you said that it was a surprise to you, I think, that the sales and your profitability were up as high as they were. Can you talk a little bit about that because if I look forw
componenttext: I'm interested. And Bruce said -- and you clearly had a very good quarter, and you said that it was a surprise to you, I think, that the sales and your profitability were up as high as they were. Can you talk a little bit about that because if I look forward for the rest of the year are these -- is the surprise you had something that suggests your ongoing performance may actually be better perhaps than you've been expecting, and the guidance just that so just wondering what you took away from the quarter and what that means for the longer term.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, Doug. I'm very happy with the first half of the year, and but I used the word surprised. I'd say we were pleasantly higher than expected or higher than planned for a couple of items, including, for instance, the ULA equity earnings
componenttext: That's a good question, Doug. I'm very happy with the first half of the year, and but I used the word surprised. I'd say we were pleasantly higher than expected or higher than planned for a couple of items, including, for instance, the ULA equity earnings that we guided in the quarter. Some of this were sort of fortuitous in terms of the mix of launch vehicles, also the pricing of the launch vehicles that we had in the quarter for ULA, for instance we had on Atlas or heavy launch which is the most expensive launch vehicle that ULA produces went off in the second quarter. That helped the earnings in the second quarter. Things like that, again, for the first half of the year all helped us. a little bit about wild in the cellar necessarily translate into full year. And I'll say, we kind of gave the first half performance in the outlook for the year, and we definitely have the opportunities that I think you're alluding to, Doug, in the second half of the year but we have to make those happen and sometimes think don't work out as planned, that's the reason we give the guidance that we did but nothing taken away from we feel very, very good and pleased with the first half performance of the year.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Myles Walton with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Myles Walton with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just a follow-up on with a little more specificity on Aeronautics. I'm curious why the second half EBIT implied in the guidance is flat to maybe down the touch versus the first half on higher volume. And then I think you're also recovering the restr
componenttext: Maybe just a follow-up on with a little more specificity on Aeronautics. I'm curious why the second half EBIT implied in the guidance is flat to maybe down the touch versus the first half on higher volume. And then I think you're also recovering the restructuring expenses you had in the first quarter, so is there a mix, something else, maybe Bruce that you can help us explain why Aeronautics isn't going to outperform that guidance?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question, Myles. So I kind of answered the question from Doug. I'd like to think we have sort of as I said in previous calls, the same sort of opportunities to have a good second half as we had in the first half, the one currently most notable change
componenttext: Good question, Myles. So I kind of answered the question from Doug. I'd like to think we have sort of as I said in previous calls, the same sort of opportunities to have a good second half as we had in the first half, the one currently most notable change from first half to second half is the fact that we had some F-35 production step-ups in the first half of the year, particularly on sort of the winding down of LRIP 7 aircraft deliveries and little bit of step-up on LRIP 8 as we go into a higher ramp right there. We don't currently have plans for F-35 production step-ups for the rest or for the second half of the year, so that's one of the things that we'll cause the second half of the year to look a little lighter probably than the first time of the year. And then secondly, the volume level of F-35, as i alluded to, and the reason for the change in our guidance for the year is really significant -- is really expected to be higher in the second half, and that has that dilutive effect of the over our margins of Aeronautics as I talked about in the past. Those 2 reasons netted to F-35. One was the step-ups that occurred in first half and secondly, it's just the volume in the second half.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel with Jefferies.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marillyn, you put one of your top managers at Sikorsky to run the business. Could you give us sort of a 6-month read on where you are and how it's going? I mean it looks to me like it's a little more expensive out-of-the-box than one would have first thou
componenttext: Marillyn, you put one of your top managers at Sikorsky to run the business. Could you give us sort of a 6-month read on where you are and how it's going? I mean it looks to me like it's a little more expensive out-of-the-box than one would have first thought.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you're right about putting one of our top folks there. We have Dan Schultz who ran large businesses for us in the past and also a helicopter pilot out of the Marine Corps those the business extremely well will doing a great job there. I'll tell you
componenttext: Well, you're right about putting one of our top folks there. We have Dan Schultz who ran large businesses for us in the past and also a helicopter pilot out of the Marine Corps those the business extremely well will doing a great job there. I'll tell you I'm really excited about the couple of things, Howard, that we've seen in the past 6 months. First off, we're tracking to what we have planned. I mean, well, from your perspective may be different but frankly, we're right on plan is with the track what I'm excited about the some of the revenue synergies that we see just by getting the integration process well underway and getting our teams together. For example, I was at the Farnborough airshow as I mentioned earlier, and we showcased an armed Black Hawk helicopter that's taking up and systems in sensors and things from our muscles on fire control business combining it with the platform that's and Mission Systems and Training Sikorsky business and showcasing that at our show in Farnborough, and we had tremendous amount of interest in it. A lot of customers are now following up with us on interest there, so that's just one. example. We've got many other examples where our teams are getting together and we see a chance to do just what we thought when we purchased Sikorsky and that is to not only get the cost synergies to bring that element into a business but also more importantly to get the revenue synergies and get the growth moving forward in it. So we're on track were talking for this call about our commercial line of Sikorsky and the oil and gas price pressures on that business, but we've been very frank about where we stand in that and based on outlook was, what we set for the year, we're right on track with that as well.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to add a little bit to what Marillyn said relative to the armed Blackhawk, I think it's an interesting little tidbit there. So you should think of this as essentially taking a utility helicopter platform and essentially transitioning it into an attac
componenttext: Just to add a little bit to what Marillyn said relative to the armed Blackhawk, I think it's an interesting little tidbit there. So you should think of this as essentially taking a utility helicopter platform and essentially transitioning it into an attack platform, the interesting thing from the way the design was conceived and the way will be sold internationally especially is you can remove that capability. So within a day's time or so, the weapons packages and so forth that are put on to make this an armed platform can be removed from the helicopter in the next the it can go out and perform a mission of the utility helicopter. That's some flexibility that doesn't exist right now in the marketplace, and that's something we think is very interesting that frankly would not have happened but for the synergy between our Missiles and Fire Control organization, our MST organization and obviously Sikorsky now.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Ron Epstein with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Ron Epstein with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe a quick update post Farnborough on what's going on with the trainer program and the time line for that and how you expect it to go?
componenttext: Maybe a quick update post Farnborough on what's going on with the trainer program and the time line for that and how you expect it to go?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the program as you were referring to, I guess where that stands right now is we are standing by with what we consider to be a very good offering excellent solution. It's low-risk. It's -- we've got it's the T50A, our joint venture with Korean airspa
componenttext: So on the program as you were referring to, I guess where that stands right now is we are standing by with what we consider to be a very good offering excellent solution. It's low-risk. It's -- we've got it's the T50A, our joint venture with Korean airspace. It's flying right now. We've ha our first slide of our operating so we've taken that T50KI and converted it into T58 to meet the requirements of the Air Force has outlined, and we're excited about the fact that demonstrating it, and we think we have and excellent offering. And the RFP appears to be slipping out. It's slipping out into the December time frame. So I think that what I understand is to the Air Force One revisit what they've outlined as requirements for that capability, and they will slip the RFP out some, and we stand ready to support that. But in the meantime, we are continuing to roll out our capabilities and showcase that capability. It's a big program. It's about 350 aircraft, so it's an opportunity for us. In our case, there is some discussion around whether or not the Air Force wants to pursue a clean sheet design or an existing design, we believe that with tremendous gap on the training capabilities of the T38 is, I don't think it's [indiscernible] 15 years old or something like that, they need to replace that aircraft and the fact that we have a low-risk aircraft that's already flying that can meet today's requirements we think we're offering something that would allow the U.S. Air Force to move forward on the program and meet that capability. There are other offerings out there as well that are not clean sheet, and so we'd like to compete, and we think we have a tremendous offering.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Shapiro with Shapiro Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Shapiro with Shapiro Research.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bruce, a couple of quick things. Previously you had said that with allied this transaction that you advice sufficient stock to offset the dilution. Given where the stocks are now, you'd probably have to use all of the $1.8 billion and maybe even a touch m
componenttext: Bruce, a couple of quick things. Previously you had said that with allied this transaction that you advice sufficient stock to offset the dilution. Given where the stocks are now, you'd probably have to use all of the $1.8 billion and maybe even a touch more to offset the dilution. So is that still the intent? And then second, you took about a $30 million charge it looks like on the international contract that you alluded to in the Q1 document, and I was just wondering if you think that's the end of it.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So relative to the share count reduction and well if that's enough to offset the dilution effects of losing the IS&GS earnings or not, you're right at the call. When we announced the deal back in January, we said that the share buyback was essentially goi
componenttext: So relative to the share count reduction and well if that's enough to offset the dilution effects of losing the IS&GS earnings or not, you're right at the call. When we announced the deal back in January, we said that the share buyback was essentially going to be enough to make the sort of neutral between the 2 years. Since that time, our stock has increased. If I look at today, it's up almost 25% over what the number was in January. I think we were trading at around $210 a share the day we announced the deal. So pretty significant increase on our side, which makes it obviously more expensive to buy back the same number of shares we had expected in the January call. On the other hand, the Leidos stock price has dropped a little bit since that time, so both of those are sort of working against us from shares perspective that will be taken out as a result of the RMP transaction. So as we sit today, George, even with 1.8, it's probably difficult to get exactly to neutral, but it gets a lot closer there. We still think the economics of this deal relative to all options that we looked at on outright sale appears spin, this is still the best situation for Lockheed Martin and its shareholders, and we don't have regret on that, notwithstanding the fact that to your point we actually are seeing a little bit of EPS dilution as a result of the stock price movement. I think that's a little bit of a high-class problem that we're experiencing right now but nonetheless, that is where we are. As to the charge we took, we did take an additional charge, $30 million, you're right. This is sort of the command-and-control business that we're looking. So think of this as sort of a system that controls all sorts of air missile defense capabilities around an entire country, including identifying friends or foes so that you don't have the wrong issues with that air missile defense capability. So linking into a lot of different systems we think we have prospects once this system is developed in other places internationally, but we've had some growing pains, obviously with this, and I think as we've gone through the development and early stages of this program, the customer has kind of changed some of what their expectations are, so we are in discussions with the customer right now about sort of closure of this contract. We think where it sits right now, it's pretty well positioned in terms of the charges we've taken. There's some upside potential to that depending on where the customer wants to have. There could be some downside so we're kind of in the middle of that right now, George, and obviously, will keep you apprized as we go through future quarters and let you know how we're performing on a that contract.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Rob Spingarn with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Rob Spingarn with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back to the F-35. Bruce, you've talked about double-digit margins, I think, in '19. And in context with the 2 new initiatives that Marillyn spoke about that were announced last week, I guess it's around $430 million in new cost and clearly, bot
componenttext: Just going back to the F-35. Bruce, you've talked about double-digit margins, I think, in '19. And in context with the 2 new initiatives that Marillyn spoke about that were announced last week, I guess it's around $430 million in new cost and clearly, both you and the government are trying to get the best deal done here on 9 and 10. Is that still about trajectory and how have margins been tracking lately?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So that is still the objective, and I'll just -- a slight correction maybe on what you said. The 2 initiatives sort of the second part of the blueprint for affordability and sustainment it is more like about $420 million. I'll remind you, this is --
componenttext: Yes. So that is still the objective, and I'll just -- a slight correction maybe on what you said. The 2 initiatives sort of the second part of the blueprint for affordability and sustainment it is more like about $420 million. I'll remind you, this is -- yes, I think your question was that share, and it is in fact shared between ourselves Northrop Grumman and just as the first blueprint for affordability initiative was. I started to see these are investments, and we expect to get returns on their investments. We're getting a return on the blueprint for affordability 1. We would expect to get returns on blueprint for affordability 2 as well as the sustainment investment that we're making. But notwithstanding that, I still think on a trajectory in the F-35 program, I think I've said more than having the specific year relating more to them when we get full rate production that we hope to get to double-digit margins by that time. I've always said it's similar points in time with the program's life cycle it all to look like an F-16 program or an F-22 or C-130, there's sort of nothing structural that would prevent us from getting to those levels. And right now, we're sort of tracking towards that trajectory. We've not come off that at all.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Strauss with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Strauss with UBS.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bruce, hate to do it but going back on pension. I think previously you had said FAS/CAS for 2017 kind of all things being the same discount rate hitting your assume rate of return would be about a $450 million positive relative to 2016, so I wanted to cla
componenttext: Bruce, hate to do it but going back on pension. I think previously you had said FAS/CAS for 2017 kind of all things being the same discount rate hitting your assume rate of return would be about a $450 million positive relative to 2016, so I wanted to clarify your answer on the prior pension question where you talked about $350 million. Are you talking about $350 million worse off the projected 2017 level or off of the actual 2016 level? And then the other thing, the $1.8 billion that you're getting in conjunction with the closing on IS&GS, would you potentially look at that for an early pension contribution to potentially offset some of the downside?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I probably wasn't at my clearest when I made that reference in the first quarter. I think I heard feedback as we went around and invest in conference and so forth I think I stumbled with they're quite honestly so I tried to be clear this time obviousl
componenttext: And I probably wasn't at my clearest when I made that reference in the first quarter. I think I heard feedback as we went around and invest in conference and so forth I think I stumbled with they're quite honestly so I tried to be clear this time obviously I'm still not being clear, but let me try to be as crystal clear as I can this thing. So FAS/CAS in 2016, the benefit is about $975 million or so. What I said is I would expect to be between -- if we struck the line of the sand right now, probably $350 million to $400 million lower than the 2016 FAS/CAS benefit in 2017. I mean, to do the math, that kind of translates into $625 million, $600-ish million income number, down considerably from what we were talking about in the first quarter of last year, almost all of that because of the discount rate change in the 1,000 -- or not 100 basis points as I talked about. back to Rich's question, it's a noncash item, will not affect our 2017 contributions at all, and that relates to your question relative to the $1.8 billion and would we use that to fund and prefer the pension plan. The answer is we don't have expectation sitting here today, and I don't think that's what we will do with the money. As I said earlier to another question I think the more likely outcome is probably share repurchases at this point in time, and we'll fund the 2018 requirement in 2018. We've already got, quite honestly, fairly sizable prepayment credit balance in terms of how much we contributed to our reserve versus what we've collected from government contracts, and we don't see the point at this time to sort of increasing that level.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes the line of Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen and Company.

componenttext: In the quarter, you had a reasonable book to bill of 0.85 in IS&GS yet my understanding is that number excluded the FAA contract, you got recently the protested ISR award you had in the second quarter. As you -- and you also mentioned, the Australian contract had another schedule delay. Can you update us as you look at next year what the IS&GS, any color on where the IS&GS numbers might be?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016

componenttext: So kind of think that's probably crossing into an area where better suited to point you to the prospectus that we've got for the RMT transaction rather than me comment on what IS&GS sales would look like under Lockheed Martin in 2017 when it's not our expectation.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes in the line of Carter Copeland with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes in the line of Carter Copeland with Barclays.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the F-35, just to clarify it. On the second part, the sustainment initiative on reducing those costs, you said 10% reduction there or $1 billion in 5 years implies, clearly, a very large sustainment amount, a $10 billion amount that see
componenttext: Just a question on the F-35, just to clarify it. On the second part, the sustainment initiative on reducing those costs, you said 10% reduction there or $1 billion in 5 years implies, clearly, a very large sustainment amount, a $10 billion amount that seem kind of large. I wondered if you could clarify if that was correct. And then secondly, with respect to the contract action, if you end up getting a UCA on this in the coming quarter or 2 quarters, Bruce, is there a particular cost margin impact to 1 contract outcome versus another that you're considering in your guidance or in the plan? How should we think about that in terms of how that gets finalized with the customer?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just take the first one on the blueprint for affordability for sustainment. What we announced was an investment of up to $250 million over the next couple of years, much like we did on blueprint for affordability for protection, this time for susta
componenttext: Let me just take the first one on the blueprint for affordability for sustainment. What we announced was an investment of up to $250 million over the next couple of years, much like we did on blueprint for affordability for protection, this time for sustainment along with and Northrop Grumman. And we're targeting over that 5-year period that we would reduce sustainment cost by 10%, so that's where the $1 billion savings for that 5-year period would come from. We've got a lot of projects that we've outlined and so it will be jointly with the U.S. government they will approve those projects we'll implement them. And as Bruce said earlier, we will get a return on our investment. So I think that answers the question and unless there's something more there, Bruce, that you want to add.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nothing to that. I'll try to address the F-35 LRIP 9 and 10, maybe a little bit more than you want, quarter but there are sort of 2 ways we could get cash recovery on this program. One is what's called an undefeated sized contractual action or UCA, we don
componenttext: Nothing to that. I'll try to address the F-35 LRIP 9 and 10, maybe a little bit more than you want, quarter but there are sort of 2 ways we could get cash recovery on this program. One is what's called an undefeated sized contractual action or UCA, we don't care frankly how we get the cash. If it comes under gets funded essentially and allows you to bill against with progress payments. So we would not recover as much cash under our although we would still get a significant amount of cash under funding mechanism as we would if we actually definitize contract because under the LRIP 10 9 and 10 you would expect to have performance-based payments and performance-based payments where we are in the contracted they would actually give us greater cash recovery that are I hope that made sense. As to impact on margins and so forth I wouldn't expect 1 or the other to have any impact whatsoever that only sort of economic impact that we're seeing and we have rates in the government is depending on how long this shortfall lasts, and I gave you some numbers relative to the shortfall, we could be -- if we choose to fund -- and again, avoid the disruption of the particularly disappointed in the program and the international partners in the program, if we chose to fund, we probably want to get in the commercial paper market bigger than we are, and it's not something we look forward to and that's probably something we got to have a conversation about what's equitable if, in fact, that takes place with the government. So potential for a negative on the commercial paper, but we would expect that there potentially could be some consideration for that if, in fact, that's what happened but that is not our plan as I said.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we've come up top of the hour, so I'll turn it back over to Marillyn for final thoughts.
componenttext: I think we've come up top of the hour, so I'll turn it back over to Marillyn for final thoughts.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jerry. As we conclude the call today, I want to wrap up again by highlighting the corporation completed an exceptional quarter, and we continue to build on our year-to-date momentum. With an increase in DoD budget and a robust backlog, the corpora
componenttext: Thanks, Jerry. As we conclude the call today, I want to wrap up again by highlighting the corporation completed an exceptional quarter, and we continue to build on our year-to-date momentum. With an increase in DoD budget and a robust backlog, the corporation is positioned for top line growth and strong cash flows in the future. Thank you again for joining us in the call today, and we look forward to speaking with you in a next earnings call in October. Cat, that concludes the call for today.
