I think the wildcard here is when I said that, I didn't expect to have the significant amount of growth on the F-35 program, particularly the sustainment piece of the F-35 program going from 2016 to 2017. I mean it's just amazing the growth that we're seeing on the sustainment program compared to what we previously thought, at least what I previously thought and what I was basing that margin comment on. So the margin that aero will likely be a little bit lighter in 2017 than it was in 2016. And most of that, but maybe not all of that, is driven by the F-35 significant ramp-up and again what I will always call the margin-dilutive algebraic effect of just a lower margin program growing faster than the rest of the business area, and that has dilutive effect on the margins. But as we look forward in the 2018 and I did tee up the C-5 and the F-16. Again, F-16 is not changing total sales volume all that much, although the aircraft quantities are coming down. C-5 is actually, again, a little bit dilutive to the overall margin. But because of the F-35 growth, it's occurring again between '18 and '17. I think the margin's kind of stay fairly constant probably as we look at this time for 2017 and 2018.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from George Shapiro with Shapiro Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from George Shapiro with Shapiro Research.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bruce, I wanted to pursue the F-35 a little bit more. Deliveries this quarter were less than last year's quarter. And actually, year-to-date, I think you went behind. So can you just comment on what that is causing that and what will it be in the fourth q
componenttext: Bruce, I wanted to pursue the F-35 a little bit more. Deliveries this quarter were less than last year's quarter. And actually, year-to-date, I think you went behind. So can you just comment on what that is causing that and what will it be in the fourth quarter. And on that score, if I just look at your guidance, it implies over $5 billion of revenues in Aeronautics in the fourth quarter, which is usually a strong quarter, but the step-up is much more than what we've seen in the past, so if you could discuss that. And then last, if I look at the $300 million of higher F-35 sales you called out, profit only up $25 million, so 8.3% implied margin. That's a little lower than we've seen in the past. So maybe if you could comment on that.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, you got your money's worth there. Good job. So F-35 deliveries, I should remind you this is a POC cost-to-cost contract, so the revenue is not impacted by deliveries, but you did make the right observation, George. The deliveries were light -- lig
componenttext: George, you got your money's worth there. Good job. So F-35 deliveries, I should remind you this is a POC cost-to-cost contract, so the revenue is not impacted by deliveries, but you did make the right observation, George. The deliveries were light -- lighter than the third quarter than we'd otherwise suggest, and this is primarily because and I know you guys have read about this, but we have these insulation tubes that affected a number of our aircraft in the field as well as the aircraft being produced. And while we have the fix for that issue in place, think of this as a supplier-driven item that we had a sort of an out-of-spec delivery that was installed in the aircraft. And as we go through and fix those for the aircraft in the field, we're also going back and fixing the aircraft that are affected with those lines in production, and that is going to cause us to end up a little lighter in F-35 deliveries this year than what we previously had said. We think we know the solution for that, as I said. And we think the recover such that by the end of 2017, we're sort of back on contractual schedule, and hopefully sooner than the end of 2017, but that's the expectation right now. The other thing you talked about was F-35 being greater than $5 billion in the quarter or Aeronautics being greater than $5 billion in the quarter. That is -- that will be the highest quarter, I think, in the history of Aeronautics, but that's sort of tracking, George, to what we expect the annual run rate to look like in 2017. Years ago, we had talked about the Aeronautics business area being about a $20 billion per year revenue business in 2015. It turns out we were close, but that's likely going to happen now in 2017 as opposed to 2015. So that's tracking right with our expectations. And then the last question on the $300 million in sales and the risk retirements, and I think you said 8-point-something percent profit, that's sort of in line with what we've done. We've had quarters previous in this year that were higher, but that's because we had some of the risk retirements that we're talking to Howard about earlier that occurred in previous quarters. When we have those risk retirements, we kind of get a spike in the margin. We just didn't have as many this quarter, so the run rate you're seeing there is about the run rate without risk retirements in the quarter.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rob Spingarn with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rob Spingarn with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bruce, I want to go back to Rich's question on the 3-year goal, back on Slide 14, but if I understand you correctly, you're going to these next 3 years with the same cash flow goal, maybe a little higher, despite a $3 billion to $4 billion headwind from p
componenttext: Bruce, I want to go back to Rich's question on the 3-year goal, back on Slide 14, but if I understand you correctly, you're going to these next 3 years with the same cash flow goal, maybe a little higher, despite a $3 billion to $4 billion headwind from pension contributions, if we take '18 and '19 and add that together, if I heard that right. And so you talked about F-35 and Sikorsky providing some revenue and earnings growth as an offset, how much more is coming from cash reimbursement? In other words, when we think about this, what is the underlying revenue increase? And how do the margins trend with that revenue?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first comment, Rob, is you did hear it right, that is what we said, and I think you got the math to all that correct. And honestly, that's an interesting question because, actually, the sort of the CAS recover -- or the pension recovery associated
componenttext: Yes. So first comment, Rob, is you did hear it right, that is what we said, and I think you got the math to all that correct. And honestly, that's an interesting question because, actually, the sort of the CAS recover -- or the pension recovery associated with CAS is diminishing going forward. So again, we talked about '15 to '17 having a pension holiday, that means we did -- we're not going to make pension contributions, so significant level of sort of pension recovery because of that. Going forward, this is what I was trying to convey in my remarks, while we have pension contributions at the level that you just described, the CAS recovery is also increasing pretty significantly and stays fairly high throughout this entire time frame. And that's again, essentially -- not essentially, but a good chunk of that is recovering that $7 billion of sort of pre-fund credit that we have at the end of this year. So that has to sort of come back at some point in the CAS billings that we have in the government. That's what sustains us over that time, even though the net cash for pension is coming down, the offset is due to operational cash going up.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Strauss with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Strauss with UBS.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bruce, to follow up on that question and another question, the CAS recovery, which I think in 2016 is $2 billion, I think you've said $2.3 billion in '17 previously. What does that grow to out in by 2019? And then my other question on Sikorsky performing
componenttext: Bruce, to follow up on that question and another question, the CAS recovery, which I think in 2016 is $2 billion, I think you've said $2.3 billion in '17 previously. What does that grow to out in by 2019? And then my other question on Sikorsky performing better than I think your initial guidance for this year, I think you talked about intangibles coming down next year. I thought it was more around integration cost coming down, but if you could just give us an idea of what operating profit of Sikorsky or margins might look out of Sikorsky on an all-in-all end basis next year.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thank you, David. So on the CAS side, you got the numbers right for both '16 and '17. And rather than give you a precise for '18 and '19, I'll just say that CAS increases in 2018 over 2017, and it increases again in 2019 over 2018. You should think o
componenttext: Yes. Thank you, David. So on the CAS side, you got the numbers right for both '16 and '17. And rather than give you a precise for '18 and '19, I'll just say that CAS increases in 2018 over 2017, and it increases again in 2019 over 2018. You should think of those as several hundreds millions of dollars kind of levels between each year there. And that's, again, back to Rob's question, that's one thing that's driving the cash recovery over that period of time. Sikorsky is doing better than we had expected, at least through the first 3 quarters of this year. I think we started off with probably a little more conservative view of Sikorsky, just a little bit of not knowing the business as well as I think we do now. And so we've seen some performance improvements or some risk retirements, I should say, in the third quarter that translate into better performance than we were seeing in the first 2 quarters of the year. I think you also talked about the changes in intangible. And I might have misspoken. I think I was talking about conforming accounting and intangible amortization all rolled up into one. And there's definitely some reductions in some of the conforming accounting adjustments as well as I think one of the things that I teed up in the January call was there was about $30 million or $40 million of sort of severance cost left over in 2016 from a severance action that was taken in the middle of January -- middle of 2015 that does not repeat itself in 2017. That, along with sort of lower integration costs in 2017 compared to 2016, is what's driving the improvements that I talked about.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Harned with Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Harned with Bernstein.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: On F-35, I wanted to go back to what you said before about performance being ahead of your expectations, and particularly around sustainment. I'm curious as to, first, why was it a surprise that sustainment was larger than you thought. And then second, wh
componenttext: On F-35, I wanted to go back to what you said before about performance being ahead of your expectations, and particularly around sustainment. I'm curious as to, first, why was it a surprise that sustainment was larger than you thought. And then second, when you look forward, how does this larger amount of sustainment work? How do you see that going forward? Does that change the way that you look at the margin trajectory for the F-35 over the next few years?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good questions, Doug. I'll take that one on. So the performance -- that you described as performance, I wouldn't necessarily characterize as performance, just the growth in sustainment activity that we see. And why was I surprised or why did I seem l
componenttext: Yes. Good questions, Doug. I'll take that one on. So the performance -- that you described as performance, I wouldn't necessarily characterize as performance, just the growth in sustainment activity that we see. And why was I surprised or why did I seem like I was surprised. I think, to a certain extent, this is a little bit -- I won't say out of our control entirely, but it is dependent upon when the government establishes sort of the base setups for the induction of F-35 aircraft and what level of support those bases need in order to be ready to take on operational F-35 aircraft. And I'll say we were probably a little conservative or maybe a lot conservative in our forecast as far as thinking that the level -- if you just think of all the things that have to be at a base, day 1, when you start delivering aircraft to that base and all the alternate mission equipment, all the support equipment and things to pull aircraft around, ladders to get on there, I mean, you could just get on all the stuff that has to go into a base. And I'll say we were probably pretty light on that forecast until we had some of those bases under our belt. And now we have some of those bases under our belt and we have a better understanding of what sort of the average needs are of the aircraft going forward. And so that's what we're projecting going forward, and I think we've got a much better handle on that going forward than we have in the past. That's all good news as far as I'm concerned. Looking forward, you asked about the margin trajectory. I wouldn't expect to see huge swings in margin associated with sustainment. We typically get margins on sustainment and they're kind of negotiated concurrently with the aircraft program. They're kind of negotiated at about similar levels of profitability, so I wouldn't expect to see a swing either way because of production or sustainment. It might remind you that, over time, the development program, the SDD contract is winding down over time. And again, that will end eventually, unless we continue to put development efforts on there, but that's going down next year. That's one of the things that's helping to mitigate some of the Aeronautics loss dilution from the F-35 program.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes the line of Carter Copeland with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes the line of Carter Copeland with Barclays.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I'd also like to extend the thanks to Jerry should you choose to ride off into the Florida sunshine before the next quarter. You've been a real force for our world. Look, just a couple of clarifications in the interest of time. One, Bruce, the pension
componenttext: And I'd also like to extend the thanks to Jerry should you choose to ride off into the Florida sunshine before the next quarter. You've been a real force for our world. Look, just a couple of clarifications in the interest of time. One, Bruce, the pension contribution of 1.5 to 2 you mentioned for '18 and '19, correct me if I'm wrong, I thought that used to be 1.5. If that changed, I wondered if you could just tell us kind of what drove that. And then the second one is on the profit delta on the C-130 that you called out in the release, it looks like that's sort of 1,200 basis points lower. How much of that should we think as sort of difference in booking rate under the new contract versus adjustments unrelated to volume that are different year-over-year?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Carter, for the questions. So I teed up the $1.5 billion, I think, a while back. And no, I think it's -- I gave a range today as you no doubt picked up from $1.5 billion to $2 billion. You should think about it as just sort of asset returns c
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Carter, for the questions. So I teed up the $1.5 billion, I think, a while back. And no, I think it's -- I gave a range today as you no doubt picked up from $1.5 billion to $2 billion. You should think about it as just sort of asset returns compounding and whether or not, we're probably giving a little leeway there as far as we've assumed 8% returns going forward. We resumed about a 5% return on assets in 2017. The underperformance to the 8% has a compounding effect that says you have to have higher CAS contributions going forward, and that's simplistically the reason for the range we're giving today is simply the asset returns. C-130, previous years, we did have some pretty good size pickups or step-ups or risk retirements relative to the third quarter last year, but you're also seeing, as you described it, sort of the lower booking rate on the newly negotiated multiyear contract that has an effect of having a lower profit rate than we've seen in the past years on the C-130 program.

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Maybe final comments here by Marillyn?

headline: Lockheed Martin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jerry. Well, so as we conclude the call today, I'd like to end by reiterating that the corporation completed an excellent quarter, and we continue to build on our momentum. We have a robust backlog and as we look at increasing DoD budget, we're we
componenttext:
Thanks, Jerry. Well, so as we conclude the call today, I'd like to end by reiterating that the corporation completed an excellent quarter, and we continue to build on our momentum. We have a robust backlog and as we look at increasing DoD budget, we're well positioned for top line growth and strong cash flows in the future. 
Before we the leave the call today, I also want to take a moment to recognize that this is Jerry's last earnings call. And before he retires at the end of this year, and Jerry, thank you for everything that you've done for me and for the corporation. You're truly the consummate IR professional, and you will be missed as you've heard from some of your colleagues on the phone today. And let me, at this time, also welcome Greg Gardner, who is Jerry's successor. Most of you known Greg for several years. Jerry and Greg will work over the next few months to ensure that there's a smooth transition. 
So again, thank you for joining us on the call today. We look forward to speaking to you in the next earnings call in January when we will review our 2016 full year results and provide our formal 2017 guidance. Andrea, that concludes the call today.
